com.navis.framework.persistence

Class DatabaseHelper

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.navis.framework.persistence.DatabaseHelper
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    HSQLDatabaseHelper, MysqlDatabaseHelper, OracleDatabaseHelper, PostgresDatabaseHelper, SqlserverDatabaseHelper

    public abstract class DatabaseHelper
extends java.lang.Object
    Utilities to help out with database operations which are generally speaking, not related to the OR mapping we are doing. Often dealing with metadata or used when a Hibernate context is not yet available. The methods which are safe to use without a valid Hibernate context are so noted. Some methods may require a valid Hibernate context.

    It is the superclass for MySQL, Postgres, SQL Server, HSQL and Oracle helpers.

    Author:
    , actually multiple. Curently under andrey.ignatenko@navis.com management

        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnName - column name
        Returns:
        FuzzyBoolean.TRUE if the column is an identity in SQL Server FuzzyBoolean.FALSE if the column is not an identity in SQL Server FuzzyBoolean.UNSPECIFIED for nonSQLServer table or an error

      • alterColumnToStringType

        public void alterColumnToStringType(@NotNull
                                    java.lang.String inTableName,
                                    @NotNull
                                    java.lang.String inColumnName,
                                    int inSize)
        This method modifies a column to "string" type like varchar, varchar2. Following hibernate declared types could be converted to "string": byte, date, double, float, integer, long, short, time, timestamp, boolean NOTE. Restiction: it works if a column has single column index or single column contraint on it. In case of compound index or composite contrant, you have to manually: drop index/constraint, modify column, then restore index/constraint
        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnName - column name
        inSize - size of varchar in chars

                                                                    int inSize)

      • makeColumnNullable

        public final void makeColumnNullable(@NotNull
                                     java.lang.String inTableName,
                                     @NotNull
                                     java.lang.String inColumnName)
        If the given column is not nullable, make it nullable. If it is nullable, nothing should happen.

        DOESN'T WORK WITH image and text for SQLServer (deprecated types),

        WARNING: Be aware that making a column nullable might affect performance.

        WARNING: This is a heavyweight action on MySQL and SQL Server as it requires the system to clone the entire column as "null" vs. "not null" is considered a different type and the column mutation can be done only through duping the row.

        Parameters:
        inTableName - database table name
        inColumnName - database column name

      • makeColumnNotNullable

        public final void makeColumnNotNullable(@NotNull
                                        java.lang.String inTableName,
                                        @NotNull
                                        java.lang.String inColumnName,
                                        @NotNull
                                        java.lang.String inDefaultValue)
        If the given column is nullable, make it not nullable. If it is not nullable, nothing should happen.

        DOESN'T WORK WITH image and text for SQLServer (deprecated types),

        WARNING: This is a heavyweight action on MySQL and SQL Server as it requires the system to clone the entire column as "null" vs. "not null" is considered a different type and the column mutation can be done only through duping the row.

        This method assumes there are no dependent objects like constraint and indexes. If there are such dependencies, drop them first, call the method then restore dropped objects.

        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnName - column name
        inDefaultValue - default value to be inserted instead of nulls if already exist in the table. TIME and TIMESTAMP data types it should be enclosed in single parenthesis. See more usages in DatabaseHelperSaTestSuite

      • jtUpdate

        public int jtUpdate(@NotNull
                    java.lang.String inUpdateString)
        This method executes jdbc template to update records in the database.
        Parameters:
        inUpdateString - updating query to execute
        Returns:
        number of updated records

      • dropIndex

        public final int dropIndex(@NotNull
                           java.lang.String inTableName,
                           @NotNull
                           java.lang.String inIndexName)
        Drop the index for a given table. Will throw sql exception if index does not exist or cannot be dropped. The table name is not used in the case of an Oracle index and can be set to null. This method is fast.
        Parameters:
        inTableName - database table name
        inIndexName - database index name
        Returns:
        number of updated records

        public final void dropIndexIfExists(@NotNull
                                    java.lang.String inTableName,
                                    @NotNull
                                    java.lang.String[] inColumnNames)
        This method drops an index if it exists based on table name and list of indexed columns. This method is useful if an index name is unknown. This method is fast.

        inColumnNames - array of column names

        @Deprecated
public final boolean dropConstraintByColumnNames(@NotNull
                                                              java.lang.String inTableName,
                                                              @NotNull
                                                              java.lang.String[] inColumnNames)
        Deprecated. in favor of dropFKConstraintByColumnNames or dropUniqueConstraintByColumnNames or dropCheckConstraintByColumnNames
        This method drops all types of constraints, except PRIMARY KEY types When drop UNIQUE constraint for Oracle, be aware of second constraint for auto-generated index
        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnNames - array of column names. Warning! order of columns does matter.
        Returns:
        true if corresponding constraint was found and dropped and false if not

      • getFindConstraintByColumnNamesQuery

        @Deprecated
protected abstract java.lang.String getFindConstraintByColumnNamesQuery()
        Deprecated. see findFKConstraintNameByColumnNames, findUniqueConstraintNameByColumnNames, findCheckConstraintNameByColumnNames or findPKConstraintNameByColumnNames
        This method returns specific query for a database to find a constraint by column names
        Returns:
        query

      • dropUniqueConstraintByColumnNames

        public boolean dropUniqueConstraintByColumnNames(@NotNull
                                                 java.lang.String inTableName,
                                                 @NotNull
                                                 java.lang.String[] inColumnNames)
        This method drops Unique constraints In SQL Server, you can create UNIQUE constraint or UNIQUE index. But they both are the same thing and serve the same purpose. However dropping them are a little different. If you create UNIQUE constraint (i.e. CREATE TABLE xxx CONSTRAINT UNIQUE constraint_columnA UNIQUE (columnA) ), then you must drop the constraint. If you create UNIQUE index (i.e. CREATE UNIQUE INDEX index_columnA ON xxx (columnA)), then you can simply drop the index. In our case we create unique constraint along with the table, so we have to drop constraint. This method is ovewrridden for Mysql it just drops the index
        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnNames - array of column names. Warning! order of columns does matter.
        Returns:
        true if corresponding constraint was found and dropped and false if not

      • findUniqueConstraintNameByColumnNames

        @Nullable
public java.lang.String findUniqueConstraintNameByColumnNames(@NotNull
                                                                         java.lang.String inTableName,
                                                                         @NotNull
                                                                         java.lang.String[] inColumnNames)
        This method finds Unique constraint by column names
        Parameters:
        inTableName - table name
        inColumnNames - array of column names
        Returns:
        constraint name (index name in case of mysql) or null if unsupported database if not found

      • addIndex

        protected boolean addIndex(java.lang.String inTableName,
                           java.lang.String inColumnName,
                           java.lang.String inIndexName,
                           boolean inIsIndexForDescOrder)
        Creates a new index for one given column. If inIndexName is specified as null, the method builds index name, based on table name and column names Otherwise specicied inIndexName applies. If flag inIndexDescOrder is set to true, the index will be Currently only supporting SQLServer and MySQL WARNING: MySQL does not support descending indices
        Parameters:
        inTableName - database table name
        inColumnName - database column name
        inIndexName - name for column, if null new built name will be used
        inIsIndexForDescOrder - true for DESC; NOTE: DESC not supported on MySQL and Postgres
        Returns:
        true if successful, false if the index already exists or wrong database type

      • addIndex

        protected boolean addIndex(java.lang.String inTableName,
                           java.lang.String inIndexName,
                           java.lang.String[] inColumnNames,
                           boolean[] inIsDescending)
        Creates a new multi-column index. If flag inIndexDescOrder is set to true, the index will be created in Descending order

        WORKS WITH: Oracle 9+, MySQL, SQL Server, Postgres, HSQL

        WARNING: MySQL does not support descending indices

        Parameters:
        inTableName - database table name
        inIndexName - name for column
        inColumnNames - array of column names to index
        inIsDescending - array of flags to indicate descending order (true) for column if null all assumed to be ascending; NOTE: DESC is not supported on MySQL (it is parsed, but ignored)
        Returns:
        true if successful, false if the index already exists or wrong database type

        public abstract void modifyBinaryToBlob(@NotNull
                                        java.lang.String inTableName,
                                        @NotNull
                                        java.lang.String inColumnName)
        Prerequisites for Oracle: 1. Modified long raw shouldn't have constraints (except NULL or NOT NULL).

        3. No PLSQL procedures call this table
        4. Undo space should be sufficient to keep altered table

                             int inLength)

      • alterVarcharColumnLength

        public void alterVarcharColumnLength(java.lang.String inTableName,
                                     java.lang.String inColName,
                                     int inNewLength)
        This method must be used to increase the size of a database String type column. In order to reduce a size, create new column or apply specific to a database commands.
        Parameters:
        inTableName - database table
        inColName - column name to alter
        inNewLength - new length

      • getAlterVarcharColumnLengthStatement

        protected abstract java.lang.String getAlterVarcharColumnLengthStatement(java.lang.String inTableName,
                                                                         java.lang.String inColName,
                                                                         int inNewLength)

      • isSupportedVersion

        public abstract boolean isSupportedVersion()
        This method verifies if the current database version is supported by Navis
        Returns:
        is it supported or not

      • isOracleRacSystem

        public abstract boolean isOracleRacSystem()
        Checks if the system is Oracle RAC system
        Returns:
        whether this is a RAC system

      • getTransactionIsolationLevel

        public java.lang.Integer getTransactionIsolationLevel()
        This method retrievs actual default transaction isolation level from a connection in the datasource. This method borrows a new connection and get this info from it.
        Returns:
        level or 0 if problems

      • processSql

                                   java.lang.String inSqlFile)
        This method executes SQL from a file
        Parameters:
        inOutMessageCollector - message collector
        inSqlFile - file with SQL commands
        Returns:
        message collector

      • getDatasourceUserName

        connected username
